semantic_title: Present on Admission (POA) Indicator Assignment for Perinatal Conditions
section_path: Present on Admission Reporting Guidelines > Perinatal Conditions

content.full_text: Newborns are not considered to be admitted until after birth. Therefore, any condition present at birth or that developed in utero is considered present at admission and should be assigned 'Y'. This includes conditions that occur during delivery (e.g., injury during delivery, meconium aspiration, exposure to streptococcus B in the vaginal canal). (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
content.summary: Guidelines for assigning POA indicators to perinatal conditions, with newborns considered admitted after birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
key_concepts: Newborn admission timing after birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
In utero conditions considered present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
Birth conditions considered present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
Delivery complications for newborns (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Newborns are not considered to be admitted until after birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
detailed_rules.explanation: The admission time for newborns is defined as after the birth process is complete (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Any condition present at birth or that developed in utero is considered present at admission and should be assigned 'Y' (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
detailed_rules.explanation: Since admission occurs after birth, all conditions existing at or before birth are considered present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

detailed_rules.rule_text: This includes conditions that occur during delivery (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
detailed_rules.explanation: Delivery-related conditions affecting the newborn are considered present at admission since admission occurs after delivery (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify condition as affecting newborn
Step 2: Determine if condition was present at birth, in utero, or during delivery
Step 3: Assign POA indicator 'Y' for all such conditions
Step 4: Only assign 'N' for conditions developing after birth/admission

references_to.title: Congenital Conditions and Anomalies
references_to.explanation: Both deal with conditions present from birth

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Newborn sustained clavicular fracture during vaginal delivery
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify birth injury as perinatal condition
Step 2: Recognize injury occurred during delivery
Step 3: Since newborn admission is after birth, injury is present at admission

correct_coding.rationale: Delivery conditions are considered present at admission for newborns (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect since delivery injuries are present at newborn admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Treating delivery timing as after admission for newborns

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Newborn delivered with thick meconium, developed meconium aspiration syndrome
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify meconium aspiration as delivery-related condition
Step 2: Recognize condition occurred during birth process
Step 3: Since newborn admission is after birth, condition is present at admission

correct_coding.rationale: Conditions occurring during delivery are present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect since delivery conditions are present at admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not recognizing delivery timing relative to newborn admission

coding_scenarios.scenario: Newborn with exposure to streptococcus B in vaginal canal
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Newborn delivered vaginally, mother positive for Group B Strep, newborn exposed during delivery
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify GBS exposure as delivery-related condition
Step 2: Recognize exposure occurred during delivery process
Step 3: Since newborn admission is after birth, exposure is present at admission

correct_coding.rationale: Exposure during delivery is considered present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect since delivery exposures are present at admission

breakdown.delivery_timing: Occurred during birth process (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
breakdown.admission_timing: Newborn admission after birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)

examples.rationale: Delivery conditions are present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

breakdown.delivery_condition: Occurred during birth process (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
breakdown.present_at_admission: Condition exists when newborn is admitted (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

examples.rationale: Conditions occurring during delivery are present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

examples.scenario: Exposure to streptococcus B in vaginal canal

breakdown.vaginal_exposure: Occurred during delivery process (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
breakdown.admission_status: Present when newborn admitted after birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)

examples.rationale: Delivery exposures are considered present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)

warnings: Newborn admission timing is after birth, not during labor (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
All delivery-related conditions are present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
best_practices: Consider all birth and in utero conditions as present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
Understand unique timing of newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
common_mistakes: Treating delivery complications as not present at newborn admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
Misunderstanding when newborn admission occurs (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
tips: Remember newborn admission is post-birth (Evidence: pg no: 120, L18-L19)
Include delivery conditions as present at admission (Evidence: pg no: 120, L19)
implementation_notes: Applies to all newborn and perinatal conditions
Unique admission timing concept for newborns
